event: The Big Bang - The universe is born.
The Sun is formed from a giant gas cloud.
The Earth is formed from cosmic dust and gas.
First life appears in the form of simple bacteria.
Oxygen appears in Earth's atmosphere due to photosynthesis.
Dinosaurs evolve and rule the Earth.
A massive asteroid wipes out the dinosaurs.
Homo sapiens (modern humans) appear.
People in Mesopotamia and Egypt develop the first units of measurement to trade goods and build monuments.
The Cubit Rod (a ruler used for measuring) is created in ancient Egypt, helping in construction and farming.
Babylonians use Pythagorean triples, an early form of mathematics, to measure land and build structures.
Ancient Egyptians develop fractions, making calculations for trade, construction, and farming easier.
Indian sage Maharshi Kanada proposes the idea of atoms, calling them 'paramanus,' a concept similar to modern atomic theory.
Pythagoras and Indian mathematicians discover that a triangle with sides 3, 4, and 5 forms a right angle, a key concept in geometry.
Greek philosopher Democritus suggests that everything is made of tiny invisible particles called 'atoms.'
Eratosthenes calculates Earth's circumference using shadows and simple geometry.
Greek scientist Archimedes discovers how objects float in water, leading to the Archimedes' Principle.
The first paper is invented in China, making writing and learning easier.
Algebra is introduced by Persian mathematician Al-Khwarizmi, helping future generations in math and engineering.
The first microscope is invented, allowing scientists to see tiny bacteria and cells.
Robert Hooke discovers cells while looking at cork under a microscope.
Isaac Newton publishes the laws of motion and gravity, explaining how objects move and fall.
Benjamin Franklin proves that lightning is electricity using a kite and a metal key.
Dmitri Mendeleev creates the Periodic Table, organizing all the chemical elements.
Alexander Fleming discovers penicillin, the first antibiotic that can cure bacterial infections.
James Watson and Francis Crick describe the double-helix structure of DNA, helping us understand genetics.
Neil Armstrong becomes the first human to walk on the Moon during Apollo 11.
Scientists complete the Human Genome Project, mapping all human genes.
The Higgs boson particle is discovered at CERN, explaining how particles gain mass.
